description: A distributed workflow manager that helps solve the problem of Hadoop job dependencies, making it easier to schedule and manage workflows in large-scale data processing environments.

name: Bonita (⭐140)
description: An open-source BPMN engine that comes with a designer and optional development environment, making it easier to build and automate complex business processes.

name: Cadence (⭐7.5k)
description: A fault-tolerant, stateful code platform that makes it easier to build and manage complex, long-running applications.

name: Camunda (⭐3.7k)
description: An open-source workflow and decision automation platform that helps you automate business processes and decisions in a flexible and scalable way.

name: Conductor (⭐12k)
description: A cloud-based orchestration engine designed to run and manage workflows in a microservices architecture.

name: Elsa Core (⭐5.4k)
description: A library that enables workflow execution in any .NET Core application, making it easier to automate business processes in .NET environments.

name: Flowable (⭐7.1k)
description: A set of open-source business process engines that are compact and efficient, making it easier to automate business processes in a scalable and reliable way.

name: jBPM (⭐1.5k)
description: A toolkit for building business applications that helps you automate business processes and decisions, making it easier to manage complex workflows.

name: StackStorm (⭐5.8k)
description: A robust automation engine that provides sensors, triggers, rules, workflows, and actions to help you automate and orchestrate complex workflows and applications.

name: Temporal (⭐8.9k)
description: An open-source platform that uses a workflow-as-code approach to make your applications more reliable and scalable.

name: Aggregator
description: How do we combine the results of individual, but related messages so that they can be processed as a whole?

name: Canonical Data Model
description: How can you minimize dependencies when integrating applications that use different data formats?

name: Channel Adapter
description: How can you connect an application to the messaging system so that it can send and receive messages?

name: Channel Purger
description: How can you keep 'left-over' messages on a channel from disturbing tests or running systems?

name: Claim Check
description: How can we reduce the data volume of message sent across the system without sacrificing information content?

name: Command Message
description: How can messaging be used to invoke a procedure in another application?

name: Competing Consumers
description: How can a messaging client process multiple messages concurrently?

name: Composed Message Processor
description: How can you maintain the overall message flow when processing a message consisting of multiple elements, each of which may require different processing?

name: Content Enricher
description: How do we communicate with another system if the message originator does not have all the required data items available?

name: Content Filter
description: How do you simplify dealing with a large message, when you are interested only in a few data items?

name: Content-Based Router
description: How do we handle a situation where the implementation of a single logical function (e.g., inventory check) is spread across multiple physical systems?

name: Control Bus
description: How can we effectively administer a messaging system that is distributed across multiple platforms and a wide geographic area?

name: Correlation Identifier
description: How does a requestor that has received a reply know which request this is the reply for?

name: Datatype Channel
description: How can the application send a data item such that the receiver will know how to process it?

name: Dead Letter Channel
description: What will the messaging system do with a message it cannot deliver?

name: Detour
description: How can you route a message through intermediate steps to perform validation, testing or debugging functions?

name: Document Message
description: How can messaging be used to transfer data between applications?

name: Durable Subscriber
description: How can a subscriber avoid missing messages while it is not listening for them?

name: Dynamic Router
description: How can you avoid the dependency of the router on all possible destinations while maintaining its efficiency?

name: Envelope Wrapper
description: How can existing systems participate in a messaging exchange that places specific requirements on the message format, such as message header fields or encryption?

name: Event Message
description: How can messaging be used to transmit events from one application to another?

name: Event-Driven Consumer
description: How can an application automatically consume messages as they become available?

name: Format Indicator
description: How can a message`s data format be designed to allow for possible future changes?

name: Guaranteed Delivery
description: How can the sender make sure that a message will be delivered, even if the messaging system fails?

name: Idempotent Receiver
description: How can a message receiver deal with duplicate messages?

name: Invalid Message Channel
description: How can a messaging receiver gracefully handle receiving a message that makes no sense?

name: Message
description: How can two applications connected by a message channel exchange a piece of information?

name: Message Dispatcher
description: How can multiple consumers on a single channel coordinate their message processing?

name: Message Expiration
description: How can a sender indicate when a message should be considered stale and thus shouldn`t be processed?

name: Message Translator
description: How can systems using different data formats communicate with each other using messaging?

name: Message Broker
description: How can you decouple the destination of a message from the sender and maintain central control over the flow of messages?

name: Message Bus
description: What is an architecture that enables separate applications to work together, but in a decoupled fashion such that applications can be easily added or removed without affecting the others?

name: Message Channel
description: How does one application communicate with another using messaging?

name: Message Endpoint
description: How does an application connect to a messaging channel to send and receive messages?

name: Message Filter
description: How can a component avoid receiving uninteresting messages?

name: Message History
description: How can we effectively analyze and debug the flow of messages in a loosely coupled system?

name: Message Router
description: How can you decouple individual processing steps so that messages can be passed to different filters depending on a set of conditions?

name: Message Sequence
description: How can messaging transmit an arbitrarily large amount of data?

name: Message Store
description: How can we report against message information without disturbing the loosely coupled and transient nature of a messaging system?

name: Messaging Bridge
description: How can multiple messaging systems be connected so that messages available on one are also available on the others?

name: Messaging Gateway
description: How do you encapsulate access to the messaging system from the rest of the application?

name: Messaging Mapper
description: How do you move data between domain objects and the messaging infrastructure while keeping the two independent of each other?

name: Normalizer
description: How do you process messages that are semantically equivalent, but arrive in a different format?

name: Pipes and Filters
description: How can we perform complex processing on a message while maintaining independence and flexibility?

name: Point-to-Point Channel
description: How can the caller be sure that exactly one receiver will receive the document or perform the call?

name: Polling Consumer
description: How can an application consume a message when the application is ready?

name: Process Manager
description: How do we route a message through multiple processing steps when the required steps may not be known at design-time and may not be sequential?

name: Publish-Subscribe Channel
description: How can the sender broadcast an event to all interested receivers?

name: Recipient List
description: How do we route a message to a list of dynamically specified recipients?

name: Request-Reply
description: When an application sends a message, how can it get a response from the receiver?

name: Resequencer
description: How can we get a stream of related but out-of-sequence messages back into the correct order?

name: Return Address
description: How does a replier know where to send the reply?

name: Routing Slip
description: How do we route a message consecutively through a series of processing steps when the sequence of steps is not known at design-time and may vary for each message?

name: Scatter-Gather
description: How do you maintain the overall message flow when a message needs to be sent to multiple recipients, each of which may send a reply?

name: Selective Consumer
description: How can a message consumer select which messages it wishes to receive?

name: Service Activator
description: How can an application design a service to be invoked both via various messaging technologies and via non-messaging techniques?

name: Smart Proxy
description: How can you track messages on a service that publishes reply messages to the Return Address specified by the requestor?

name: Splitter
description: How can we process a message if it contains multiple elements, each of which may have to be processed in a different way?

name: Test Message
description: What happens, though, if a component is actively processing messages, but garbles outgoing messages due to an internal fault?

name: Transactional Client
description: How can a client control its transactions with the messaging system?

name: Wire Tap
description: How do you inspect messages that travel on a point-to-point channel?

name: API-led Connectivity pattern
description: Use APIs to connect different systems and applications.

name: Anti Corruption Layer Pattern
description: Add a layer to isolate and transform data between systems.

name: Change Data Capture Pattern
description: Capture and propagate changes made to a database or data source in real-time.

name: Hybrid API Management pattern
description: Manage APIs that span both cloud and on-premises environments using a central control plane.

name: Hybrid Integration pattern
description: Integrate systems and applications that are deployed both on-premises and in the cloud using a combination of integration technologies.

name: Frontend Integration
description: How can client-side end-user interfaces that are physically separated from server-side business logic and data storage be populated and updated with computing results, result sets from searches in data sources, and detailed information about data entities? How can application frontends invoke activities in a backend or upload data to it?

name: Frontend Integration
description: How can client-side end-user interfaces that are physically separated from server-side business logic and data storage be populated and updated with computing results, result sets from searches in data sources, and detailed information about data entities? How can application frontends invoke activities in a backend or upload data to it?

name: Backend Integration
description: How can distributed applications and their parts, which have been built independently and are deployed separately, exchange data and trigger mutual activity while preserving system-internal conceptual integrity without introducing undesired coupling?

name: Public API
description: How can an API be made available to an unlimited and/or unknown number of API clients outside the organization that are globally, nationally, and/or regionally distributed?

name: Community API
description: How can the visibility of and the access to an API be restricted to a closed user group that does not work for a single organizational unit but for multiple legal entities (such as companies, nonprofit/nongovernment organizations, and governments)?

name: Solution-Internal API
description: How can access to and usage of an API be limited to an application, for instance, components in the same or another logical layer and/or physical tier?

name: API Description
description: Which knowledge should be shared between an API provider and its clients? How should this knowledge be documented?

name: Processing Resource
description: How can an API provider allow its clients to trigger an action in it?

name: Processing Resource
description: How can an API provider allow its clients to trigger an action in it?

name: Processing Resource
description: How can an API provider allow its clients to trigger an action in it?

name: Information Holder Resource
description: How can domain data be exposed in an API, but its implementation still be hidden? How can an API expose data entities so that API clients can access and/or modify these entities concurrently without compromising data integrity and quality?

name: State Creation Operation
description: How can an API provider allow its clients to report that something has happened that the provider needs to know about, for instance, to trigger instant or later processing?

name: State Creation Operation
description: How can an API provider allow its clients to report that something has happened that the provider needs to know about, for instance, to trigger instant or later processing?

name: Retrieval Operation
description: How can information available from a remote party (the API provider, that is) be retrieved to satisfy an information need of an end user or to allow further client-side processing?

name: State Transition Operation
description: How can a client initiate a processing action that causes the provider-side application state to change? How can API clients and API providers share the responsibilities required to execute and control business processes and their activities?

name: Computation Function
description: How can a client invoke side-effect-free remote processing on the provider side to have a result calculated from its input?

name: Operational Data Holder
description: How can an API support clients that want to create, read, update, and/or delete instances of domain entities that represent operational data: data that is rather short-lived, changes often during daily business operations, and has many outgoing relations?

name: Operational Data Holder
description: How can an API support clients that want to create, read, update, and/or delete instances of domain entities that represent operational data: data that is rather short-lived, changes often during daily business operations, and has many outgoing relations?

name: Master Data Holder
description: How can I design an API that provides access to master data that lives for a long time, does not change frequently, and will be referenced from many clients?

name: Reference Data Holder
description: How should data that is referenced in many places, lives long, and is immutable for clients be treated in API endpoints? How can such reference data be used in requests to and responses from Processing Resources or Information Holder Resources?

name: Link Lookup Resource
description: How can message representations refer to other, possibly many and frequently changing, API endpoints and operations without binding the message recipient to the actual addresses of these endpoints?

name: Data Transfer Resource
description: How can two or more communication participants exchange data without knowing each other, without being available at the same time, and even if the data has already been sent before its recipients became known?

name: Atomic Parameter
description: How can simple, unstructured data (such as a number, a string, a Boolean value, or a block of binary data) be exchanged between API client and API provider?

name: Atomic Parameter
description: How can simple, unstructured data (such as a number, a string, a Boolean value, or a block of binary data) be exchanged between API client and API provider?

name: Atomic Parameter
description: How can simple, unstructured data (such as a number, a string, a Boolean value, or a block of binary data) be exchanged between API client and API provider?

name: Atomic Parameter List
description: How can multiple related Atomic Parameters be combined in a representation element so that each of them stays simple, but their relatedness becomes explicit in the API Description and the runtime message exchanges?

name: Parameter Tree
description: How can containment relationships be expressed when defining complex representation elements and exchanging such related elements at runtime?

name: Parameter Forest
description: How can multiple Parameter Trees be exposed as request or response payload of an API operation?

name: Data Element
description: How can domain/application-level information be exchanged between API clients and API providers without exposing provider-internal data definitions in the API? How can API client and API provider be decoupled from a data management point of view?

name: Data Element
description: How can domain/application-level information be exchanged between API clients and API providers without exposing provider-internal data definitions in the API? How can API client and API provider be decoupled from a data management point of view?

name: Metadata Element
description: How can messages be enriched with additional information so that receivers can interpret the message content correctly, without having to hardcode assumptions about the data semantics?

name: Id Element
description: How can API elements be distinguished from each other at design time and at runtime? When applying domain-driven design, how can elements of the Published Language be identified?

name: Link Element
description: How can API endpoints and operations be referenced in request and response message payloads so that they can be called remotely?

name: API Key
description: How can an API provider identify and authenticate clients and their requests?

name: API Key
description: How can an API provider identify and authenticate clients and their requests?

name: Error Report
description: How can an API provider inform its clients about communication and processing faults? How can this information be made independent of the underlying communication technologies and platforms (for example, protocol-level headers representing status codes)?

name: Context Representation
description: How can API consumers and providers exchange context information without relying on any particular remoting protocols? How can identity information and quality properties in a request be made visible to related subsequent ones in conversations?

name: Embedded Entity
description: How can one avoid sending multiple messages when their receivers require insights about multiple related information elements?

name: Embedded Entity
description: How can one avoid sending multiple messages when their receivers require insights about multiple related information elements?

name: Embedded Entity
description: How can one avoid sending multiple messages when their receivers require insights about multiple related information elements?

name: Linked Information Holder
description: How can messages be kept small even when an API deals with multiple information elements that reference each other?

name: Pagination
description: How can messages be kept small even when an API deals with multiple information elements that reference each other?

name: Pagination
description: How can messages be kept small even when an API deals with multiple information elements that reference each other?

name: Wish List
description: How can an API client inform the API provider at runtime about the data it is interested in?

name: Wish Template
description: How can an API client inform the API provider about nested data that it is interested in? How can such preferences be expressed flexibly and dynamically?

name: Conditional Request
description: How can unnecessary server-side processing and bandwidth usage be avoided when frequently invoking API operations that return rarely changing data?

name: Request Bundle
description: How can the number of requests and responses be reduced to increase communication efficiency?

name: Pricing Plan
description: How can the API provider meter API service consumption and charge for it?

name: Pricing Plan
description: How can the API provider meter API service consumption and charge for it?

name: Rate Limit
description: How can the API provider prevent API clients from excessive API usage?

name: Service Level Agreement
description: How can an API client learn about the specific quality-of-service characteristics of an API and its endpoint operations? How can these characteristics, and the consequences of not meeting them, be defined and communicated in a measurable way?

name: Version Identifier
description: How can an API provider indicate its current capabilities as well as the existence of possibly incompatible changes to clients in order to prevent malfunctioning of clients due to undiscovered interpretation errors?

name: Version Identifier
description: How can an API provider indicate its current capabilities as well as the existence of possibly incompatible changes to clients in order to prevent malfunctioning of clients due to undiscovered interpretation errors?

name: Semantic Versioning
description: How can stakeholders compare API versions to detect immediately whether they are compatible?

name: Two In Production
description: How can a provider gradually update an API without breaking existing clients but also without having to maintain a large number of API versions in production?

name: Aggressive Obsolescence
description: How can API providers reduce the effort for maintaining an entire API or its parts (such as endpoints, operations, or message representations) with guaranteed service quality levels?

name: Experimental Preview
description: How can providers make the introduction of a new API, or new API version, less risky for their clients and obtain early adopter feedback without having to freeze the API design prematurely?

name: Limited Lifetime Guarantee
description: How can a provider let clients know for how long they can rely on the published version of an API?

name: Eternal Lifetime Guarantee
description: How can a provider support clients that are unable or unwilling to migrate to newer API versions at all?

name: Canonical Protocol
description: Defines a common communication protocol between services to enable interoperability and decoupling.

name: Canonical Protocol
description: Defines a common communication protocol between services to enable interoperability and decoupling.

name: Canonical Schema
description: Defines a standard data model and format for exchanging data between services.

name: Domain Inventory
description: Identifies and categorizes the types of services within a particular domain.

name: Enterprise Inventory
description: Identifies and categorizes the types of services within a particular domain.

name: Logic Centralization
description: Centralizes business logic within a service layer to reduce redundancy and promote consistency.

description: Centralizes business logic within a service layer to reduce redundancy and promote consistency.

description: Centralizes business logic within a service layer to reduce redundancy and promote consistency.

description: Abstracts data entities to simplify data access and reduce coupling.

description: Abstracts data entities to simplify data access and reduce coupling.

description: Centralizes policies to reduce duplication and improve consistency.

description: Defines a common utility layer across multiple domains.

name: Inventory Endpoint

name: Service Grid
description: Provides a framework for managing and scaling services.

name: State Repository
description: Stores and manages service state information.

name: Stateful Services
description: Maintains state information across service invocations.

name: Augmented Protocols
description: Enhances protocols with additional features.

description: Defines a standard expression language for inventory data.

description: Encapsulates service functionality for improved maintainability.

name: Partial State Deferral
description: Encapsulates service functionality for improved maintainability.

name: Partial Validation

name: Redundant Implementation
description: Implements multiple versions of a service for improved flexibility.

name: Service Data Replication
description: Replicates data across multiple services for improved performance.

name: Service Façade

name: UI Mediator
description: Mediates between the user interface and underlying services for improved usability.

name: Reference Data Centralization
description: Centralizes reference data to reduce duplication and improve consistency.

name: Microservice Deployment
description: Deploys services as independent, autonomous units for improved scalability and resilience.

name: Containerization
description: How can an environment be provided with maximum support for services with high-performance recovery and scalability requirements?

name: Exception Shielding
description: Protects against security vulnerabilities through proper handling of exceptions.

name: Exception Shielding
description: Protects against security vulnerabilities through proper handling of exceptions.

name: Message Screening
description: Screens messages for malicious content.

name: Service Perimeter Guard
description: Guards the service perimeter to prevent unauthorized access.

name: Trusted Subsystem
description: Establishes trust between subsystems for improved security.

name: Concurrent Contracts
description: Allows multiple versions of a service contract to coexist simultaneously.

name: Contract Centralization

name: Decoupled Contract

name: Validation Abstraction
description: Abstracts validation logic to improve reusability and maintainability.

description: Provides a gateway to access legacy file-based systems.

description: Breaks down a service capability into smaller, more manageable pieces.

description: Refactors a service to improve its design and performance.

name: Version Identification
description: Identifies the version of a service.

name: Capability Composition
description: Combines multiple service capabilities to create a new capability.

description: Combines multiple service capabilities to create a new capability.

description: Uses a message queue to decouple services and improve scalability and reliability.

name: Messaging Metadata
description: Uses metadata to describe and manage service messages.

name: Reliable Messaging

name: Service Agent
description: Acts as a proxy for a remote service to improve performance and reduce network overhead.

name: Service Callback
description: Uses callbacks to communicate between services.

name: Service Instance Routing

name: Service Messaging
description: Describes the communication between services.

name: State Messaging
description: Uses messages to manage state information in a distributed environment.

name: Agnostic Sub-Controller
description: Separates sub-controllers from the main controller to improve reusability and maintainability.

name: Agnostic Sub-Controller
description: Separates sub-controllers from the main controller to improve reusability and maintainability.

name: Atomic Service Transaction
description: Uses transactions to ensure atomicity and consistency across multiple service invocations.

name: Compensating Service Transaction

description: Enables services to act autonomously within a composition.

description: Authenticates clients through a broker.

name: Data Confidentiality

description: Transforms data formats to enable interoperability.

description: Transforms data models to enable interoperability.

name: Entity Linking
description: Links related resources to enable navigation and discovery.

name: Lightweight Endpoint
description: Provides a lightweight endpoint for resource access.

name: Reusable Contract
description: Reuses common contracts to improve consistency and reduce duplication.

name: Content Negotiation
description: Negotiates the content format between clients and servers.

name: Endpoint Redirection
description: Redirects clients to alternative endpoints.

name: Idempotent Capability
description: Ensures that the same action can be performed multiple times without changing the system state.

name: API Blueprint (⭐8.5k)
description: A powerful high-level language for designing and documenting APIs that allows software engineers to easily collaborate and create efficient APIs.

name: AsyncAPI (⭐3.6k)
description: An essential tool for developing Event-Driven Architectures (EDA) and enables engineers to build a better tooling ecosystem.

name: GraphQL (⭐14k)
description: A sophisticated query language and runtime for building efficient APIs that empowers engineers to retrieve data from existing systems with ease.

name: JSON:API (⭐7.2k)
description: A standardized specification for building APIs that simplifies the representation of resources, relationships, and metadata, making it easier for software engineers to create efficient APIs.

name: OpenAPI (ex.Swagger) (⭐27k)
description: A language-agnostic specification for creating RESTful APIs that enables both humans and machines to understand the capabilities of a service without the need for source code or documentation.

name: RAML (⭐3.8k)
description: A RESTful API Modeling Language that allows software engineers to design and create efficient APIs by modeling resources, endpoints, and interactions.

name: WSDL
description: A powerful XML-based interface description language for SOAP-based services that enables software engineers to describe the functionality of a web service and automate the creation of client code.

name: API-Security-Checklist (⭐21k)
description: Best practices about REST API security.

name:
Architectural Styles and
the Design of Network-based Software Architectures
description: Roy Fielding's dissertation defining REST.

name: Enterprise Integration Using REST
description: Discusses the constraints and flexibility that you have with nonpublic APIs, and lessons learned from doing large scale RESTful integration across multiple teams.

name: Richardson Maturity Model
description: Explained by Martin Fowler, originally presented by Leonard Richardson.

name: Web API Design: Crafting interfaces that developers love
description: Creating Web APIs that are consistent, intuitive, and user-friendly for developers.

name: API Designer
description: Validate your understanding of API design basics and best practices.

name: API Product Manager
description: Demonstrate your proficiency in managing APIs as products.

name: API Security Architect
description: Validate your expertise in securing APIs using modern architectures.

name: Associate Administrator Certification
description: Validates an individual's foundational knowledge and skills in managing and administering the Boomi platform, focusing on platform monitoring, troubleshooting, and security.

name: Associate Developer Certification
description: Demonstrates a candidate's basic understanding of building and deploying integration processes using the Boomi platform, including design patterns, deployment, and error handling.

name: Associate EDI for X12 Certification
description: Validates an individual's proficiency in using Boomi to design, develop, and manage Electronic Data Interchange (EDI) integrations with the X12 standard, covering essential concepts like EDI document structure and trading partner management.

name: Associate Flow Essentials Certification
description: Showcases a candidate's knowledge of creating and managing business applications using Boomi Flow, with emphasis on workflow design, user interfaces, and data integration.

name: Associate Master Data Hub Certification
description: Highlights a candidate's understanding of using the Boomi Master Data Hub to ensure data quality and consistency across systems, focusing on data modeling, governance, and synchronization.

name: Development and Application Architecture Certification
description: Confirms an individual's expertise in designing and implementing complex integration solutions and application architectures on the Boomi platform, including best practices and performance optimization.

name: Professional API Design Certification
description: Demonstrates a candidate's ability to design, develop, and manage APIs using Boomi, including RESTful API principles, API security, and versioning.

name: Professional API Management Certification
description: Validates an individual's expertise in managing the full lifecycle of APIs using the Boomi platform, including API deployment, monitoring, and analytics.

name: Professional Developer Certification
description: Recognizes a candidate's in-depth knowledge and skills in developing, deploying, and managing integration processes using Boomi, with emphasis on advanced data transformation and error handling techniques.

name: Professional Flow Developer Certification
description: Showcases an individual's advanced capabilities in designing, developing, and managing business applications using Boomi Flow, including complex workflow design, custom UI components, and integration with external systems.

name: Professional Linux Operational Administrator Certification
description: Confirms a candidate's proficiency in managing and administering Boomi on Linux systems, covering topics such as system installation, configuration, security, and performance optimization.

name: Professional Windows Operational Administrator Certification
description: Validates an individual's expertise in managing and administering Boomi on Windows systems, focusing on system installation, configuration, security, and performance optimization.

name: IBM Certified Solution Developer – App Connect Enterprise V11
description: Validate your intermediate-level knowledge and experience to develop, deploy, tune, and support platform-independent message flow applications using IBM App Connect V11.0.

name: IBM Certified Solution Implementer – API Connect v10.0.3
description: Demonstrate your intermediate-level knowledge and skills to develop, publish, configure, and manage APIs using IBM API Connect v10.0.3.

name: Event-native API Management Foundations
description: Basics of Event-native API Management.

name: Event-native API Management Professional
description: Focuses on some more advanced API Management concepts, plus foundational knowledge around how to use Gravitee API Management.

name: Kong Gateway Certified Associate
description: Validate your entry-level knowledge and skills on Kong Gateway for developers, DevOps, and architects.

name: MuleSoft Certified Developer - Level 1
description: Level 1 - Validate your knowledge and skills to design, build, test and debug, deploy, and manage basic APIs and integrations using MuleSoft.

name: MuleSoft Certified Developer - Level 2
description: Level 2 - Validate your ability to work on production-ready Mule applications that address and balance critical non-functional requirements including monitoring, performance, maintainability, reliability, and security.

name: MuleSoft Certified Integration Architect - Level 1
description: Level 1 - Validate your knowledge and skills to translate functional and non-functional requirements into integration interfaces and implementations.

name: MuleSoft Certified Platform Architect - Level 1
description: Level 1 - Validate your knowledge and skills to direct the emergence of an effective application network out of individual integration solutions following API-led connectivity across an organization using Anypoint Platform.

name: Oracle Business Process Management Suite 12c Certified Implementation Specialist
description: Validate your expertise in implementing Oracle BPM Suite 12c solution.

name: Oracle Cloud Platform Application Integration 2022 Certified Professional
description: Validate your understanding of Oracle Application Integration to implement these Cloud services.

name: Oracle Data Integrator 12c Certified Implementation Specialist
description: Validate your expertise in selling or implementing Oracle Data Integration 12c solutions.

name: Oracle SOA Suite 12c Certified Implementation Specialist
description: Validate your expertise in implementing solutions based on Oracle SOA Suite 12c.

name: Red Hat Certified Specialist in API Management
description: Validates the ability to create and maintain enterprise APIs using the Red Hat 3scale API Management platform.

name: Red Hat Certified Specialist in Business Rules
description: Checks the knowledge, skills, and abilities needed to perform tasks involving the implementation and management of business logic using the Red Hat JBoss BRMS.

name: Red Hat Certified Specialist in Cloud-native Integration
description: Validates the ability to create and maintain enterprise integration services based on Red Hat Fuse, Camel, and APIs.

name: Red Hat Certified Specialist in Event-Driven Development with Kafka
description: Validates the ability to develop applications using Apache Kafka and Apache Kafka Streams.

name: SAP Certified Development Associate - SAP Integration Suite
description: SAP Integration Suite - Validates that the candidate possesses the fundamental and core knowledge required of the SAP Integration Suite profile.

name: SnapLogic Administrator Certification
description: Assesses your ability to handle administrative tasks for SnapLogic instances.

name: SnapLogic Architect Certification
description: Evaluates your knowledge of integration reference architectures and key strategies for the SnapLogic platform, covering topics like SnapLogic Architecture, Snaplex Requirements, Pipeline Lifecycle Management, Advanced Data Transformations, API Management, Resumable Pipelines, and Best Practices.

name: SnapLogic Certified Enterprise Automation Professional
description: An advanced certification covering topics like SnapLogic platform, asset management, workflows, expression language, tasks, pipeline modularization, migration, and user assistance videos for various endpoints.

name: SnapLogic Developer Certification
description: Testing your expertise in using the SnapLogic SDK, implementing different parts of Snap functionality, and building custom Snaps.

name: SnapLogic Integrator Certification
description: Focuses on topics such as beginner training, ultra tasks, pipeline migration, and user assistance videos covering various integration endpoints.

name: TIBCO BusinessWorks Associate
description: Checks the understanding of Business Studio and TIBCO Cloud Integration, designing application components (modules, WSDL, REST API), developing integration applications, and testing, deploying, and managing applications.

name: TIBCO BusinessWorks Certified Professional
description: Validates the ability to design, develop, deploy, monitor, and manage TIBCO BusinessWorks applications of average complexity with minimal supervision.

name: TIBCO BusinessWorks Container Edition Certified Professional
description: Validates the ability to develop, deploy, and manage TIBCO BusinessWorks Container Edition applications of average complexity with minimal supervision.

name: TIBCO BPM Enterprise Associate
description: Checks the understanding of TIBCO BPM's features and capabilities, developing and managing business processes, and deploying and testing process applications.

name: TIBCO BPM Enterprise Certified Professional
description: Validates the ability to design, develop, deploy, and manage business processes using TIBCO BPM Enterprise Suite.

name: TIBCO Cloud Associate Certification
description: Validates the skills and knowledge required to work with TIBCO Cloud, including its key components and features.

name: TIBCO Cloud API Management Associate
description: Covers topics such as API definition creation and testing, API key authentication, and using the Developer Portal and I/O docs.

name: TIBCO Cloud API Management Certified Professional
description: Validates the ability to implement TIBCO Cloud Mesh, OAuth-based security, and manage SOAP services.

name: TIBCO Cloud Integration Associate
description: Validates the skills and knowledge required to work with TIBCO Cloud Integration, including its Connect, Develop, and Integrate capabilities.

name: TIBCO Cloud Integration - Connect Associate
description: Connect Associate - Checks the usage of Connect capability of TIBCO Cloud Integration, installing On-Premise Agent, creating connections and integration apps, and configuring flows.

name: TIBCO Cloud Integration - Connect Certified Professional
description: Connect Certified Professional - Checks the creation and management of connections, ensuring connection security, and troubleshooting issues related to connections in TIBCO Cloud Integration.

name: TIBCO Cloud Integration Certified Professional
description: Checks the knowledge about capabilities and benefits, integrating, developing, and connecting applications, creating APIs using the API Modeler and Mock functionality, and more.

name: TIBCO Messaging Associate
description: Covers topics such as TIBCO Enterprise Message Service (EMS), TIBCO FTL, TIBCO eFTL, as well as other messaging technologies such as Apache Kafka, Apache Pulsar, and Eclipse Mosquitto.

name: TIBCO Messaging Certified Professional
description: Validates the skills and knowledge required to work with TIBCO Messaging and its components, including TIBCO Enterprise Message Service (EMS), TIBCO FTL, and TIBCO eFTL.

name: Workato Automation Pro I
description: Fundamentals of business automation processes.

name: Workato Automation Pro II
description: Advanced and practical approaches to automation.

name: Workato Automation Pro III
description: In-depth series of badged modules for maximizing Workato's potential.

name: WSO2 Certified API Manager Developer - V3
description: V3 - Assesses your expertise in designing, developing, and publishing APIs using WSO2 API Manager V3, including API lifecycle management, access control, and API documentation.

name: WSO2 Certified API Manager Developer - V4 - Micro Integrator Profile
description: V4 - Micro Integrator Profile - Validates your expertise in designing, developing, and publishing APIs using the Micro Integrator profile of WSO2 API Manager V4. It covers API lifecycle management, access control, and API documentation within the Micro Integrator context.

name: WSO2 Certified API Manager Expert - V3
description: V3 - Confirms your advanced skills and knowledge in using WSO2 API Manager V3 for API management, including API creation, publishing, security, policy implementation, and analytics.

name: WSO2 Certified API Manager Expert - V4 - API Management Profile
description: V4 - API Management Profile - Demonstrates your proficiency in using WSO2 API Manager V4 for API management tasks, such as creating, publishing, and securing APIs, as well as implementing policies and analytics.

name: WSO2 Certified Enterprise Integrator Developer - V6
description: V6 - Validates your ability to develop, deploy, and manage integration solutions using WSO2 Enterprise Integrator V6, including knowledge of its components, such as the ESB profile, Message Broker, and Business Process Server.

name: WSO2 Certified Enterprise Integrator Developer - V7 - Micro Integrator
description: V7 - Micro Integrator - Validates your knowledge and skills in using the Micro Integrator profile of WSO2 Enterprise Integrator V7 to develop, deploy, and manage integration solutions.

name: WSO2 Certified Enterprise Integrator Developer - V7 - Streaming Integrator
description: V7 - Streaming Integrator - Demonstrates your expertise in using the Streaming Integrator profile of WSO2 Enterprise Integrator V7 to develop, deploy, and manage real-time data integration and streaming analytics solutions.

name: WSO2 Certified Enterprise Integrator Expert - V6
description: V6 - Tests your in-depth knowledge and skills in using WSO2 Enterprise Integrator V6 for complex integration scenarios, including best practices, troubleshooting, and performance tuning.

name: WSO2 Certified Solutions Architect Associate
description: Assesses your understanding of the fundamental concepts and principles of WSO2 product architecture, as well as your ability to design and implement solutions using WSO2 technologies.

name: JCA
description: Defines a standard architecture for Jakarta EE application components to connect to Enterprise Information Systems. Formerly Java EE Connector Architecture and J2EE Connector Architecture.

name: Kafka Connect
description: A tool for scalably and reliably streaming data between Apache Kafka and other systems.

name: Apache Avro (⭐2.6k)
description: Data serialization system that provides compact, fast, and efficient serialization of structured data. It supports schema evolution, allows for efficient data compression, and is designed to work well with big data processing frameworks.

name: BSON
description: Binary-encoded serialization format for JSON-like documents that is designed to be lightweight and efficient. It supports rich data types and is widely used in NoSQL databases, such as MongoDB.

name: CSV
description: A simple and widely used data format that stores tabular data in plain text. It is easy to read and write, and can be processed by most programming languages.

name: JSON
description: A lightweight and easy-to-read data format that is widely used for data exchange. It supports a wide range of data types and is compatible with many programming languages.

name: NDJSON (⭐616)
description: A standard for delimiting JSON objects in stream protocols. It allows for efficient processing of large JSON datasets and is widely used in big data processing.

name: Protocol Buffers (⭐62k)
description: A language-neutral and platform-neutral serialization mechanism that is designed to be highly efficient and extensible. It supports rich data types and is widely used in distributed systems, such as gRPC and Apache Kafka.

name: XML
description: A flexible and widely used markup language that is used for storing and exchanging structured data. It supports rich data types and is compatible with many programming languages.

name: YAML (⭐288)
description: A human-friendly and easy-to-read data serialization format that is widely used for configuration files and data exchange. It supports rich data types and is compatible with most programming languages.

name: File Transfer
description: Data is exchanged through file exchange between applications.

name: Messaging
description: Applications exchange messages using a messaging infrastructure.

name: Remote Procedure Invocation
description: Applications call functions or procedures on a remote server over a network.

name: Shared Database
description: Multiple applications access and manipulate the same data through a common database.

name: Gartner Critical Capabilities for Full Life Cycle API Management
Gartner Critical Capabilities for Full Life Cycle API Management
Gartner Magic Quadrant for Full Life Cycle API Management
The Forrester Wave: API Management Solutions
Gartner Critical Capabilities for Intelligent Business Process Management Suites
Gartner Critical Capabilities for Intelligent Business Process Management Suites
Gartner Magic Quadrant for Intelligent Business Process Management Suites
Gartner Critical Capabilities for Data Integration Tools
Gartner Critical Capabilities for Data Integration Tools
Gartner Magic Quadrant for Data Integration Tools
Gartner Critical Capabilities for Enterprise Integration Platform as a Service
Gartner Critical Capabilities for Enterprise Integration Platform as a Service
Gartner Magic Quadrant for Enterprise Integration Platform as a Service
Gartner Critical Capabilities for Robotic Process Automation
Gartner Critical Capabilities for Robotic Process Automation
Gartner Magic Quadrant for Robotic Process Automation
The Forrester Wave: Robotic Process Automation
AMQP 0-9-1
description: A message queuing protocol that enables the exchange of messages between applications or systems. AMQP 0-9-1 provides reliability, security, and flexibility to handle complex messaging scenarios.

name: AMQP 1.0
description: A widely accepted message queuing protocol that provides reliable, interoperable, and efficient messaging between systems. AMQP 1.0 supports a broad range of messaging scenarios and is ideal for complex enterprise-level applications.

name: CoAP
description: A specialized application protocol designed for constrained devices in the Internet of Things (IoT) ecosystem. CoAP offers a lightweight, low-overhead communication mechanism to support resource-constrained devices.

name: HTTP
description: A widely used protocol that facilitates communication between web servers and clients. HTTP enables the transfer of data over the internet, making it possible for web applications to function seamlessly.

name: JSON-RPC
description: A simple and lightweight remote procedure call protocol that enables communication between systems using JSON data. JSON-RPC offers stateless communication and is suitable for resource-constrained devices.

name: MQTT
description: A lightweight and efficient publish-subscribe protocol that supports messaging between devices. MQTT enables low-overhead communication and is ideal for IoT and mobile applications.

name: OpenMessaging (⭐285)
description: A cloud native, vendor-neutral open specification for distributed messaging.

name: SOAP
description: A messaging protocol that uses XML to enable communication between systems. SOAP supports a wide range of messaging scenarios, including distributed computing and enterprise applications.

name: STOMP
description: A messaging protocol that offers simple, text-oriented communication between systems. STOMP is ideal for low-latency, high-performance messaging scenarios.

name: JDBC
description: A Java-based API that provides universal data access to relational databases. JDBC offers a consistent and efficient way to access and manipulate data, making it a popular choice among developers.

name: JMS
description: A messaging API that enables Java applications to send and receive messages. JMS supports reliable messaging and is widely used in enterprise-level applications.

name: ODBC
description: A widely accepted API that provides a standardized way to access data from various database management systems. ODBC offers a consistent interface to access data, making it easy to develop database applications.

name: OData
description: An open protocol that enables the creation and consumption of queryable and interoperable REST APIs. OData simplifies the development of REST APIs and offers a standardized way to access data.

name: Standard Webhooks (⭐945)
description: Open source tools and guidelines for sending webhooks easily, securely, and reliably.

name: JSON Schema (⭐2.9k)
description: A powerful tool for validating the structure of JSON data. JSON Schema enables developers to ensure that JSON data conforms to a specific structure, making it easier to process and manipulate.

name: Schematron
description: A rule-based validation language that enables developers to define and validate business rules, data reporting, quality control, and other validation scenarios. Schematron offers a flexible way to validate XML documents.

name: XML Schema
description: A schema language that offers facilities for describing the structure and constraining the contents of XML documents. XML Schema enables developers to ensure that XML data conforms to a specific structure, making it easier to process and manipulate.
